ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK TAR:STU 36127 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
 
FOR  
 
 
GOOD PRACTICE ON PRO-POOR SERVICE DELIVERY  
 
 
BY LOCAL GOVERNMENTS 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
December 2002

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  PPA  –  participatory poverty assessment 
  RSGR  –  Governance and Regional Cooperation Division 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TOR  –  terms of reference 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by Asha Newsum.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Concept Paper for the Project was prepared by the Regional and Sustainable 
Development  Department,  Governance  and  Regional  Cooperation  Division  (RSGR),  and 
cleared by the Knowledge Management Committee in February 2002.1  
 
2.  The regional technical assistance (TA) is designed to create an enabling environment for 
developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  to  share  information  on  policies  and  measures  that 
improve local governments' responsiveness in providing basic services to the poor. The TA was 
designed on the assumption that (i) DMCs continue to face significant challenges in providing 
responsive, equitable, and affordable services, particularly to the poor and the marginalized; 
and (ii) local governments in the region have limited opportunities to learn and share information 
on policies and measures that improve responsiveness in service delivery to the poor. In 
designing the TA, the RSGR considered ADB’s involvement in pro-poor service delivery at the 
local government level and studied the preparatory work being carried out by the World Bank for 
the World Development Report 2004: Making Services Work for Poor People. The Governance 
Committee will select the participating DMCs (para. 12). Approval will be obtained from the 
concerned DMCs before the list is finalized. The TA framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  In their efforts to improve the efficiency and responsiveness of basic services, many 
DMCs  have  transferred  the  responsibility  for  service  delivery  to  local  governments.  The 
countries  where  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  is  assisting  decentralization  include 
Bangladesh, Cambodia, India, Indonesia, and Pakistan. The most common services transferred 
include primary health care, primary education, and water and sanitation. In addition, many 
governments have introduced a range of policies and measures to improve responsiveness in 
delivering public services, particularly to the poor. The new measures include participatory 
poverty assessments (PPAs), social audit as a mechanism for the community to survey service 
delivery, participatory planning, and citizens' charters. The extent to which these policies and 
practices are appropriate and effective in the context of services provided by local governments 
requires analysis. Furthermore, within local governments, there is little comparative regional 
information on (i) the impact of these efforts in improving services for poor people; and (ii) 
benchmarking2 the quality of the responsiveness in delivering services.    
 
4.  In local governments planning for delivery of services is a complex and constantly 
evolving process; it should reflect the needs of the users and involve the community and 
stakeholders.  The  issues  are  (i)  the  effectiveness  of  the  local  government’s  process  for 
assessing the needs of the poor; (ii) the level of consultation, particularly how local governments 
reach out to the poor; and (iii) the extent of feedback loops from social audits and report cards in 
the planning process. 
 
5.  A challenge that faces local governments is identifying and targeting the poor to ensure 
equitable and affordable basic services. The issues as follows (i) do all local governments in a 
DMC have a consistent definition of poverty, (ii) do the local governments have a database for 
tracking poverty incidence in their localities, and (iii) how are the poor identified?

6.  PPAs were conducted in a number of countries to inform the poverty reduction strategies 
of DMCs. The key issues are (i) the extent to which the PPA indicates the responsiveness of 
service delivery to the poor; (ii) the extent to which local governments use PPAs to enhance the 
responsiveness of service delivery; and (iii) whether PPAs are appropriate instruments for 
assessing decentralized service delivery to the poor.  
 
7.  Service delivery surveys, sometimes referred to as social audits or report cards, are 
being promoted in response to the growing pressure of bringing citizens voice and client focus 
to service delivery. The issues follow (i) do service delivery surveys cover the poor and the 
marginalized effectively; (ii) are the results of the surveys fed back into the local government 
decision-making processes to improve service delivery; (iii) to what extent are the poor involved 
in conducting the surveys; and (iv) are the surveys conducted at regular intervals to track 
changes in performance. 
 
8.  Citizens' charters have been introduced as a policy framework for service delivery in 
several  countries,  specifically  in  India  and  Bangladesh,  to  improve  the  effectiveness  and 
efficiency of public services. A key component of the policy is concerned with consulting citizens 
about the level and quality of services they receive. The issues follow (i) how effective is the 
citizens’ charter as a policy framework for improving responsiveness in service delivery; (ii) to 
what extent have local governments adopted the citizens' charter as a policy framework to 
improve  responsiveness  in  delivering  services;  (iii)  would  local  governments  benefit  from 
international experience on the use of citizens’ charters; and (iv) do central and state/provincial 
governments have a policy framework requiring local governments to use citizens’ charters to 
consult citizens—particularly the poor—in assessing the delivery of basic services. In some 
instances  local  governments  are  obliged  to  negotiate  minimum  standards  with  citizens. 
Responsiveness depends on policies adopted by service providers and is associated with 
planning and reviewing service delivery, and getting citizens’ feedback.     
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
9.  The  TA  will  (i)  study  the  policies  and  practices  adopted  by  local  governments  in 
participating DMCs to improve responsiveness in delivering services and share the findings, 
good practices, and lessons in the region; and (ii) give local governments the opportunity to 
learn  from  international  good  practice  through  a  regional  seminar  where  international 
practitioners will share knowledge and experience gained. More specifically, the TA will  
 
(i)  assess  service  delivery  planning  and  determine  whether  local  governments 
involve the community, particularly the poor, in planning; 
(ii)  determine how municipalities identify and target the poor; 
(iii)  examine whether social audits, client satisfaction surveys, and report cards are 
effective mechanisms for reviewing service delivery to the poor and improving 
responsiveness; 
(iv)  examine  whether  citizens'  charters  improve  the  responsiveness  of  service 
delivery to the poor; 
(v)  consider  opportunities  for  benchmarking  responsiveness  in  the  delivery  of 
services;

3 
(vi)  identify policies, processes, and approaches used by local governments that can 
be shared more widely for responsive service delivery in the region; and 
(vii)  facilitate regional learning and sharing of experiences and good practices to 
improve the responsiveness of services.  
 
10.  The TA intends to raise awareness of improved responsiveness of service delivery to the 
poor, specifically by disseminating the following: 
 
(i)  three case studies on international experiences and good practices; 
(ii)  three self-assessments of DMC performance and experience in service delivery; 
(iii)  action  plan  of  local  government  participants  from  DMCs  for  improving 
responsiveness of service delivery to the poor; 
(iv)  ADB’s next steps in improving responsiveness in pro-poor service delivery; and 
(v)  proceedings of the regional seminar. 
  
11.  To achieve a focused set of outputs and complement initiatives already under way in 
ADB and other agencies, the TA will not cover the role of civil society, including the private 
sector, in the actual delivery of services.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The Governance Committee3 in close consultation with the regional departments, will 
select three DMCs. There will not be more than one DMC per subregion. Further, clearance 
from the concerned DMC government will be obtained prior to implementation of the TA in the 
DMC. The key criteria for selecting are as follows: 
 
(i)  Where ADB is already involved through a program/project in improving service 
delivery through local governments; 
(ii)  Where  local  governments  have  introduced  policy  measures  for  improving 
responsiveness in service delivery; 
(iii)  Where the existing organizational arrangements can be used to establish the in-
country pro-poor service delivery team comprising local government champions4 
who will actively participate in the TA; 
(iv)  Where the institutional arrangements for the existing ADB programs/projects can 
facilitate5  the  collection  of  local  data  and  information  through  prepared  and 
structured questionnaires; and 
(v)  Where DMCs, including the identified local governments, have requested that 
they be involved in the research and knowledge exchange to be undertaken by 
the TA. 
 
13.  The Governance Committee will also need to consider whether a sector focus or a 
rural/urban focus will give more depth to the TA. 
 
                                                 
3  The Governance and Capacity Building Committee is one of the thematic committees in ADB that assist in 
influencing strategic directions and policy. 
4  Local government champions are local government officials who are involved in ADB-assisted programs/projects in 
improving  service  delivery  in  their  locality,  i.e.,  have  responsibility  for  planning,  directing,  implementing,  or 
monitoring services delivery. They should be committed to sharing information with other local government 
champions and willing to learn from the experiences of others. 
5  The TA will fund the data collection exercise.

4 
14.  After completing the selection, a pro-poor service delivery working group led by the 
governance specialist from RSGR and comprising ADB operational staff responsible for the 
existing programs/projects in the selected DMCs will be constituted. The working group will 
oversee  and  supervise  implementation  of  the  TA  to  ensure  its  relevance  to  improved 
responsiveness of service delivery in the region, and will select the local government champions 
to comprise the in-country pro-poor service delivery team. Staff from RSGR will serve as the 
secretariat for the working group and will be responsible for coordinating the TA activities. 
 
15.  After participating DMCs are selected, there will be an inception phase to address the 
following: 
 
(i)  the terms of reference for the in-country pro-poor service delivery TA teams; 
(ii)  proposal  for  bringing  in  the  experience  of  three  countries  where  the  local 
governments  have  made  demonstrable  improvements  in  service  delivery  to 
citizens,  particularly  the  poor,  and  not  as  one-off  experiments  but  as 
institutionalized practices to ensure sustainability; 
(iii)  a common format or protocol for assessing the level of responsiveness in service 
delivery by local governments in the three DMCs; 
(iv)  a proposal for the regional seminar and products and the basis for inviting and 
funding participants to the seminar; and 
(v)  a timetable for implementation and the responsibility matrix. 
 
16.  A  team  of  international  and  domestic  consultants  will  implement  the  TA.  Resource 
speakers from three local government institutions will be invited to prepare and present papers 
on best practices and lessons learned in service delivery.   
 
17.  A key feature of the TA is the establishment of in-country pro-poor service delivery 
teams  comprising  local  government  champions  that  will  (i)  assess  the  current  level  of 
responsiveness  in  delivering  services  in  their  locality,  and  (ii)  present  the  results  of  the 
assessment at a regional seminar. The local government champions will be selected for their 
involvement in ADB-assisted programs/projects to improve service delivery in their locality and 
their membership/linkages with the local government network in the DMC. The in-country teams 
will also ensure that the benefits of the TA are widely shared through existing local government 
networks.  
 
18.  The TA will culminate in the regional seminar where two sets of presentations will be 
made:  
 
(i)  a self-assessment by the participating DMCs on their levels of responsiveness in 
providing services, particularly to the poor; and 
(ii)  presentations by resource speakers from three international local government 
institutions on successful institutionalized systems and processes for improving 
responsiveness in service delivery. 
 
19.  The participants of the regional seminar will include up to four members from each 
participating  DMC  and  one  resource  person  from  each  of  the  three  local  government 
institutions. The proceedings of the seminar and the case studies will be available on the ADB 
Governance web site.

5 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $250,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s TA funding program. Details of the cost estimates are in Appendix 2.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  RSGR  will  implement  the  TA.  Participating  DMCs'  concurrence  on  the  TA  will  be 
obtained on a no-objection basis.  
 
22.  The TA will require up to 27 person-months of consulting services (5 international and up 
to 22 domestic). ADB will engage all consultants as individuals in accordance with its Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements for engaging domestic consultants. Outline 
terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
23.  The  experiences  gained  under  the  TA  will  be  disseminated  through  the  ADB 
Governance web site and a publication on lessons learned and suggested next steps will follow. 
 
24.  The TA will begin in February 2003 and be completed in November 2003. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis for 
Good Practice on Pro-Poor Service Delivery by Local Governments, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
THE WORKING GROUP AND THE RESOURCE PERSONS 
 
1.  To implement the regional technical assistance (TA), one international consultant and 
four domestic consultants (one in each developing member country [DMC] and one in Manila) 
will be appointed individually. In total, up to 5 person-months of international consulting services 
and 22 person-months of domestic consulting services will be required. 
 
A.  International Consultant 
2.  The international consultant (lead) will be an expert in improving responsiveness in 
service delivery in local governments and familiar with activities in the Asia and Pacific Region. 
He/she should have a degree in the social sciences, political science, or public administration 
and several years’ relevant experience in the region, demonstrated by direct involvement or an 
advisory role in service delivery and local government activities in poverty reduction. Experience 
in conducting structured research, analysis, and presentations in the area of local governments 
and service delivery, social audit, citizens’ charters, or service delivery planning is essential. 
 
3.  During the inception phase, the international consultant will 
 
(i)  produce terms of reference (TORs) for the in-country pro-poor service delivery 
teams; 
(ii)  prepare TORs for named international resource persons from three countries 
outside the region;  
(iii)  prepare a common format or protocol for assessing the level of responsiveness 
in service delivery of local governments in three DMCs; 
(iv)  prepare a proposal for the regional seminar and its outputs, and the basis for 
inviting and funding participants to the seminar;  
(v)  produce a timetable for implementation and the responsibility matrix; and 
(vi)  assist the members of the working group establish the in-country working teams. 
 
4.  During the implementation phase, the consultant will 
 
(i)  work  with  the  in-country  teams  to  identify  domestic  consultants  who  can 
complete the in-country assessment;  
(ii)  guide and manage the in-country teams and domestic consultants to ensure the 
assessments are completed effectively and on time; 
(iii)  supervise  the  domestic  consultant  in  Manila  to  ensure  his/her  TORs  are 
achieved;  
(iv)  link up with the resource persons from each of the three countries outside the 
region via E-mail to guide them and add value to the paper to be presented;  
(v)  ensure implementation of all tasks in accordance with a timetable produced 
during the inception phase; 
(vi)  ensure that progress of the tasks in the responsibility matrix is regularly reported 
to the working group; and 
(vii)  guide and advise the working group. 
 
5.  For the regional seminar, the consultant will 
 
(i)  review the required organizational steps and their timetable;

D.  The ADB Pro-Poor Service Delivery Working Group 
 
8.   The working group will 
 
(i)  guide the specification of the products during the inception phase; 
(ii)  attend and contribute to the periodic working group meetings; 
(iii)  ensure the TA is integrated with and contributes to the existing programs/projects 
in the regional departments; 
(iv)  ensure  that  the  selected  local  governments  participate  and  contribute  in 
implementing the TA in accordance with the TORs for the in-country teams; 
(v)  actively  help  in  identifying  the  in-country  resource  persons  required  for 
conducting the data and information gathering exercise;  
(vi)  guide implementation and mitigate risks likely to arise during the preparation of 
the TA outputs; 
(vii)  oversee the conduct of the regional seminar; 
(viii)  encourage wider participation in the regional seminar; 
(ix)  assure the quality of TA products; and 
(x)  identify the next steps after project closure. 
 
E.  Resource Persons 
 
9.  To support the implementation of the TA, three international resource persons will be 
invited to prepare and present papers on best practices and lessons learned in service delivery. 
They will be engaged on an individual basis for 20 days (which includes days for preparatory 
work, attendance in regional seminar, and postseminar work). 
 
10.  Each  resource  person  will  be  a  recognized  expert  in  improving  responsiveness  in 
service delivery in local governments. He/she will represent an international local government 
institution  involved  in  successful  institutionalized  systems  and  processes  for  improving 
responsiveness in service delivery. He/she will 
(i)  prepare  a  paper  and  present  it  in  the  regional  seminar  on  the  successful 
institutionalization of systems and processes for improving responsiveness in 
service delivery; 
(ii)  maintain contact and coordinate with the international consultant and domestic 
consultant in Manila for briefing on specific papers and how they fit together, in 
reviewing  the  presentations,  and  in  identifying  any  apparent  gaps  or  helpful 
linkages in the presentations; 
(iii)  present the paper during the regional seminar and participate in all discussions, 
meetings, and fora as required; and 
(iv)  undertake postseminar work as agreed upon with the international consultant.
